head.supplied: 13/5/85 ¶ ¶ When at Gov House this day, dear Mr Wadsworth, I learnt incidentally, that his Excellency has never seen or received yet a copy of my Eucalyptography, so I learned in conversation with La...

div.p: P85/1482, unit 41, VPRS 1163/P1 inward correspondence, VA 1123 Premier, Public Record Office, Victoria.

When at Gov House this day, dear Mr Wadsworth, I learnt incidentally, that his Excellency has never seen or received yet a copy of my Eucalyptography, so I learned in conversation with Lady Loch.
See M to R. Wadsworth, 2 October 1884. As that work is an important one for so many practical purposes, concerning our colony, perhaps you could kindly arrange that the Governor obtains a copy, — bound ones being available now. I feel sure the hon. the Premier would grant the request.

p.style: font-family: Geneva; font-size: 12pt; margin-left: 1.75in; margin-right: 0in; text-indent: 0in;
font-family: Geneva; font-size: 12pt; margin-left: 1.75in; margin-right: 0in; text-indent: 0in;
font-family: Geneva; font-size: 12pt; margin-left: 1.75in; margin-right: 0in; text-indent: 0in;

div.p:
Ferd. von Mueller
Wadsworth transferred the matter to the Secretary to the Premier, E. Thomas. Thomas noted on 15 May: 'Look into this: I distinctly remember a presenta[tio]n being authorized'. On 1 June it was noted: 'His Excellency has already received a copy'.
